Charles Derby IOS-1036742
Neuroecology of Ink Defenses

The objective of this project is to understand the function, evolution, and neural mechanisms of chemical defenses used during predator-prey interactions. The project focuses on inking animals, using as experimental models sea hares and squid as inking prey, and fish and crustaceans as their predators. Experimental techniques used in this project include behavior, electrophysiology, analytical chemistry, and molecular biology. Inking animals use their ink as a visual smoke screen, mimic, or distractor, aiding them in escaping predators. But inking animals also use ink as a chemical defense, via diverse mechanisms. The first objective is to identify cellular mechanisms of chemical deterrence, by examining how chemical defenses of inking animals (sea hares, squid) affect the chemosensory systems of predatory fish (sea catfish) and crustaceans (spiny lobsters, blue crabs). The second objective is to examine how ink chemical defenses have evolved, by determining if the molecules in ink that act as chemical defenses have other functions such as serving as alarm cues or sun screens that predate their defensive function. The investigators expect to find a diversity of mechanisms of action, including some chemicals that activate specific deterrent receptor cells that evoke neural pathways evoking rejection, and other chemicals that inhibit food receptor cells and thus turn off pathways that evoke food search and acceptance. This work will contribute to the understanding of the predator-prey relationships, by showing how animals use limited resources to defend themselves against a variety of predators with diverse sensory capabilities and attack strategies. This work will also contribute to the understanding of principles of organization of chemosensory systems.

The project also has broader impacts, including: promoting training of students, especially underrepresented groups, in the practice scientific inquiry and creative thinking and writing; providing outreach and public dissemination of information; and commercializing antimicrobial technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of our project was to understand the function, mechanisms of action, and evolution of chemical defenses. Inking molluscs – sea hares and squid – were used a model chemically-defended organisms, and crustaceans and fish were used as model predators.  Regarding function and mechanisms, ink of sea hares contains a diversity of antipredatory mechanisms.  One mechanism is phagomimicry, wherein ink serves as a decoy by virtue of its high concentration amino acids stimulating chemoreceptors that mediate feeding in predatory crustaceans, thus causing the predatory lobsters to break off their attacks on the animals as they attend to and feed on the ink.  A second mechanism is chemical deterrence through a diversity of unpalatable or aversive chemicals.  A third mechanism is ink as a conspecific alarm cue, which causes other sea hares to avoid an area containing ink.  We examined the possibility of a fourth mechanism of chemical defense: that ink inactivates the sensory systems of predators. We showed that sea hare ink forms a physical barrier against chemosensory input to lobsters, thus perturbing the reception of and response to food-related chemical stimuli by these predators. This is the first demonstration of an animal using a chemical defense to disrupt the chemical senses of a would-be predator, and it is one of the few demonstrations for sensory disruption through any sensory modality.  We extended our demonstration of ink as a chemical defense to squid, using behavioral interactions between squid and predatory summer flounder in large naturalistic laboratory conditions, as well as examining in aversive properties of squid ink against fish. Our results show that squid ink affects two phases of the attack of flounders: approach and ingestion. We extended our work on a second fish species, the sea catfish, a voracious predator, and showed not only that squid ink is a chemical deterrent but that it is the melanin-containing fraction of ink that mediates this effect.  Regarding evolution of chemical defenses, we show that one class of molecules in the ink of sea hares – mycosporine-like amino acids (MAAs) – are alarm cues to other sea hares. We tested the hypothesis that these MAAs may have evolved this function after originally being used as chemical defenses. We showed that the MAAs are distasteful to crustacean predators, supporting the hypothesis, and suggesting that MAAs are keystone molecules that have a diversity of impacts across trophic levels in marine communities.
